title: EPWP – ‘General cleaning program’ within Elias Motsoaledi Municipality in Limpopo
text:
The ‘writing is on the wall’ – the ruling party has opened the taps, and would now, in the run up of the 2016 local elections, intend to advance its tarnished and dented image and in the process would roll out projects and or programs, that should have been done long ago, and not just 8 months before the 2016 elections and also in the process regain voter support.
Such is the new EPWP program/project that is being rolled out in the Elias Motsoaledi Local Council, where 540 destitute, indigent, unemployed youth, women and people living with disabilities are being invited to apply for work opportunities over a 12 months’ time frame earning R 80.00 per day. This extrapolates to a program/project cost of R 11.232 million, but if the correct remuneration that should be paid (R85.00 per day) is used amounts to a project cost of R 16.848 million. So somewhere along the line R 5.616 millions is disappearing through the cracks!
But the most disturbing matter is that the LED Manager within the Elias Motsoaledi that is self-proclaimed to be in charge of scrutinizing applicants for the vacant positions have made it more than abundantly clear that supporters and or voters of the ANC would have preference over the employment of others in reference to the program/project and that he would be the only one to identify beneficiaries of the employment opportunities.
In the notice as issued by the Municipal Manager (Me. RM Maredi) of which the closing date is the 25 th instant, in this regard, no mention is made that employment in the project would depend on political affiliations, which it should not be, yet the Manager within its confines seems to think that he has the ‘jurisdiction and powers’ to add the criteria for consideration as a prerequisite for employment based on political affiliation.
Fourteen wards are to benefit from the program/project which in essence means that each ward should benefit for 38 employment opportunities in its ambit.
Local Councilors that represent each and every ward that is to benefit from the opportunities, whom are au fait of the most deserving cases that should have preference to employment should have the mandate and jurisdiction to nominate, elect and shortlist the applicants of the ward to be employed, and such a responsibility should not be vested in one person alone, which makes ‘ex gratia’ opportunities easier and less controllable.
For once let there be accountability, transparency and good clean governance, and not to use an opportunity to gain and score political points.
Let the recruitment be above board, a-political, and to advance employment and alleviate poverty in the area for once without having any personal agenda in its methodology and or even any undertone that may raise suspicion and cast doubt on the integrity of people
